Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Bridging the Supply Chain Information Gap Using Micro-Logistics Internet of Things (IoT)
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of a micro-logistics solution to address multi-billion-dollar challenges facing supply chains due to coarse item-level visibility and tracking. The complexity of today’s supply chain makes it difficult to optimize micro-logistics processes, such as quality control, inventory tracking, re-stocking, traceability, deadline projections, and indoor transport. The commercialization of a micro-logistics Internet of Things (IoT) may bridge the physical with the digital world, providing significant visibility and enhanced analytics, potentially saving billions of dollars.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of technology for high-precision, robust, and real-time positioning. The proposed technology may transform billions of already-deployed, batteryless Radio-Frequency IDentification (RFIDs) tags into powerful micro-location sensors. The proposed technology relies on a wireless excitation protocol combined with innovations in signal processing, super-resolution algorithms, and sensor network architecture. It has been tested in practical real-world environments, demonstrating the ability to achieve centimeter-scale positioning in challenging indoor environments.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The complexity of today’s supply chain makes it difficult to optimize micro-logistics processes, such as quality control, inventory tracking, re-stocking, traceability, deadline projections, and indoor transport. The commercialization of a micro-logistics IoT can bridge the physical with the digital world, providing significant visibility and enhanced analytics, potentially saving billions of dollars. This I-Corps project is based on the development of technology for high-precision, robust, and real-time positioning. The proposed technology may transform billions of already-deployed, batteryless Radio-Frequency IDentification (RFIDs) tags into powerful micro-location sensors. The proposed technology relies on a wireless excitation protocol combined with innovations in signal processing, super-resolution algorithms, and sensor network architecture. It has been tested in practical real-world settings, demonstrating the ability to achieve centimeter-scale positioning in challenging indoor environments.


The key project outcomes have identified: 1) Three potential customer segments (AMR, piece-picking robots, retail stockroom). 2) A quantified value proposition for the most promising beachhead market (retail stockroom). 3) key partners, activities, resources, and financial forecasts (cost structure and revenue streams)


We conducted  interviews with decision-makers and end-users across warehouse robotics, fully-integrated retailers, piece-picking robotics companies, and solution integrators, and we identified three specific use cases. The first is “retail backstock cycle counting”  where fully-integrated retailers who have already adopted RFIDs need to identify and locate SKUs in the backstock. In this use case, our solution can provide real-time visibility, enabling store associates to quickly find and retrieve items in the backstock. The second use case is “cycle counting using AMR robots”; Autonomous Mobile Robots (AMRs) have seen growing adoption in warehouses and distribution centers, and our solution can be integrated into the AMRs  in order to enable cycle-counting using the mobile platform to reduce shrinkage and/or increase real-time stock visibility. The third use case is “verification for piece-picking robots”, which are used in e-commerce fulfillment. Today’s piece-picking robots perform vision-based verification (e.g., barcodes) which is prone to errors and visual occlusion; in contrast, by using the RFID-based micrologistics solution, we can double the throughput, which is the #1 metric for e-commerce fulfillment. Our discussions with potential customers also delved into pricing strategies for each of these solutions. 

 

In parallel to the NSF I-Corps, we applied for and received a PFI award, which aims to enable us to conduct translational research to mature the technology in a manner that is horizontal across these application domains. We will continue our customer development to narrow the beachhead market to one of these three use cases as well as identify the first out-of-lab customer pilot as part of our commercialization plan. At this stage, we hypothesize that 'Backstock Cycle Counting' is the most attractive beachhead based on market size and readiness.


We intend to proceed with our commercialization in tandem with the three stages of customer acquisition in the supply chain market. The first stage is demonstrating an in-lab prototype for the customer in the context of the target use case; this involves translational research, and will be supported through the PFI to demonstrate an in-lab prototype for initial partners. The second stage in commercializing in this market typically involves on-site pilots (e.g., in a retail store). This stage requires additional research and development, which will require hiring hardware and software engineers to integrate with the WMS software already used by customers as well as to perform benchmarking and performance optimization. We plan to fund this second stage through an SBIR Phase 1 grant, followed by an SBIR Phase 2, which will be focused on building the SaaS model and acquiring the next ten customers. Subsequently, we plan to raise additional funding from venture capital as we scale production, marketing, and sales.
